title: Working Hours & Rest Periods
legalBasis: Workers' Statute (Royal Legislative Decree 2/2015) Articles 34-37; Royal Decree 1561/1995 on special working hours; EU Working Time Directive 2003/88/EC; Royal Decree-Law 8/2019 on working time recording; Applicable collective agreements
summary:
Working time and rest period regulations protect workers' health, safety, work-life balance, and ensure fair compensation for work performed. The Workers' Statute establishes maximum working hours, minimum rest periods, and overtime limits that employers must respect. In hospitality, where long hours, irregular schedules, and evening and weekend work are common, understanding and enforcing these limits is particularly important. Article 34 establishes maximum ordinary working time of 40 hours per week averaged annually, maximum nine hours per day, and minimum rest breaks. Article 35 limits overtime to 80 hours annually. Articles 36 and 37 establish minimum daily and weekly rest periods and annual holiday entitlement.

The hospitality sector presents specific working time challenges: demand fluctuates dramatically requiring flexible scheduling, service periods create intense work rushes, evening and night work is standard, split shifts fragment the workday, and weekend and holiday work is routine. These factors create risks of excessive working hours, insufficient rest, work-life conflict, and chronic fatigue. Royal Decree 1561/1995 provides some flexibility in working time organization for hospitality, allowing averaging over longer reference periods and certain exceptions to standard limits, but fundamental protections — particularly rest periods and maximum hours averaged over time — remain binding.

Since 2019, Royal Decree-Law 8/2019 mandates that employers maintain daily records of actual start and end times worked by each employee. This requirement, a response to widespread working time violations particularly in sectors like hospitality, provides transparency and evidence for enforcement. Workers have the right to access their time records, and these records must be available for labor inspections. Violations of working time limits expose employers to administrative sanctions, labor claims for unpaid overtime or inadequate rest compensation, and in cases causing health harm, potential occupational health liability.
keyPoints: Maximum ordinary working time is 40 hours per week averaged over annual reference period
Maximum daily working time is 9 hours unless collective agreement permits longer daily shifts with compensatory reductions
Minimum rest break of 15 minutes required when working day exceeds 6 continuous hours
Minimum daily rest between working days is 12 hours (11 hours in some sectors with collective agreement provision)
Minimum weekly rest is 1.5 days (36 hours) uninterrupted per week, preferably including Sunday
Overtime is limited to maximum 80 hours per year and must be voluntary except force majeure situations
Overtime compensation is by payment at enhanced rate or compensatory time off within four months
Employers must maintain daily time records showing exact start and end times for each worker
Workers have right to access their own time records to verify accuracy and compliance
Night work (22:00-06:00) for night workers cannot exceed 8 hours average per 24-hour period over 15-day reference

sections.heading: 1. Ordinary Working Time Limits and Distribution
sections.content:
Article 34 of the Workers' Statute establishes that maximum ordinary working time is 40 hours per week of actual work on average annually. The annual averaging provision allows weekly working time to vary above and below 40 hours as long as the average over the year does not exceed 40 hours. This flexibility accommodates seasonal businesses (summer beach restaurants, winter ski resorts) and establishments with fluctuating demand, allowing longer hours during busy seasons compensated by shorter hours in slow periods. However, averaging does not permit indefinite excessive hours; the maximum daily limit of 9 hours and minimum rest requirements constrain how much weekly variation is possible.

The distribution of working time within the day and week must be established by collective agreement or, in its absence, by agreement between employer and worker. Many hospitality collective agreements specify standard working patterns: split shifts common in restaurants (morning and evening service with afternoon break), continuous shifts in hotels or 24-hour operations, variable shifts determined by business needs with advance notice requirements. The distribution must comply with daily maximum (9 hours) and minimum rest requirements (12 hours between working days, 15-minute break for shifts over 6 hours).

Flexible working time arrangements are increasingly common, particularly in response to unpredictable demand. Collective agreements may establish: irregular time distribution (distribución irregular de la jornada) allowing employers to modify working hours within defined limits and with specified advance notice (typically one week); variable shift rosters where workers receive schedules in advance but specific days and hours vary; or on-call arrangements where workers must be available to work if called with appropriate compensation for availability. Any flexible arrangements must respect legal limits and should be clearly specified in individual contracts or communicated policies.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Split Shifts in Hospitality
subsections.content:
Split shifts (jornada partida), where workers work a morning period, have an unpaid break of several hours, and return for an evening period, are extremely common in hospitality. A typical split shift might be 12:00-16:00 and 20:00-24:00 (8 hours actual work spread over 12 hours). While legal, split shifts create significant work-life interference: workers are committed to work for most of the day but are paid only for hours actually worked, the break is often insufficient to return home meaningfully, and the fragmented day makes it difficult to manage personal responsibilities or have a social life.

Split shifts count only actual working hours toward the 40-hour weekly maximum; unpaid break time is excluded. However, some collective agreements provide compensatory measures for split shifts, such as: limiting the maximum split (for example, break cannot exceed 4 hours); requiring higher total salary for split shift workers; limiting the number of split shifts per week; or providing additional rest days. Workers should check whether their collective agreement provides such protections and ensure they are applied. Some regions or agreements are moving toward continuous shifts (jornada continua) as more worker-friendly alternatives.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Part-Time Work and Working Hours
subsections.content:
Part-time workers have proportionately reduced working hours compared to comparable full-time workers. Part-time contracts must specify exact working hours and distribution (specific days and times) or at minimum provide predictability through defined schedules provided with specified advance notice. Voluntary supplementary hours (horas complementarias) may be agreed in writing, allowing employers to require additional hours up to 30% of contracted hours with defined advance notice. Workers can refuse supplementary hours in certain circumstances (care responsibilities, education, incompatibility with another job).

Part-time workers' rights are protected by equal treatment principles: they must not be discriminated against regarding pay rates, benefits, or working conditions compared to full-time workers. Prorated entitlements (holiday, leave, extra payments) must be calculated proportionately to hours worked. Overtime rules apply to part-time workers, with overtime being hours exceeding ordinary full-time hours for the sector (typically 40 hours weekly); hours between contracted part-time hours and full-time hours are not overtime but may be supplementary hours with different compensation rules. Part-time workers should carefully verify that contracted hours match actual hours worked regularly and that all hours are properly recorded and compensated.

sections.heading: 2. Rest Breaks, Daily Rest, and Weekly Rest
sections.content:
Rest periods are essential for recovery, preventing fatigue, and maintaining health and safety. Article 34.4 of the Workers' Statute requires a minimum 15-minute rest break when the continuous working day exceeds 6 hours. This break must be an actual rest period — workers must be free from duties, able to leave the work area, and not on-call. In practice, hospitality workers often struggle to take breaks during busy service periods, but employers remain legally obligated to provide breaks and cannot require workers to forgo breaks. Some collective agreements provide more generous breaks (for example, 20 minutes after 6 hours, or breaks for shorter shift durations).

Daily rest between working days must be at least 12 consecutive hours. This means from the end of one shift to the start of the next shift, at least 12 hours must elapse. For example, finishing work at midnight means the next shift cannot start before noon the following day. The 12-hour minimum is increased to 14 hours for workers under 18. Some collective agreements with longer averaging periods for working time may reduce daily rest to 11 hours (the EU directive minimum) on some days compensated by longer rest on others, but such provisions must be explicit in the agreement.

Weekly rest must be at least 1.5 consecutive days (36 hours) per week, preferably including Sunday. For establishments open seven days per week (hotels, restaurants, bars), weekly rest is typically scheduled as one full day plus a half-day, or two full days, on a rotating basis ensuring all workers receive weekly rest. Weekly rest periods can be accumulated over 14-day periods in some sectors (for example, working 12 consecutive days then having 3 days off), but maximum limits on consecutive working days without rest typically apply. Sunday work is not prohibited but should be compensated (premium pay, supplementary rest days, or other compensation specified in collective agreements).

subsections.heading: 2.1 Rest Period Violations and Compensation
subsections.content:
Violations of rest period requirements can occur when employers schedule shifts with insufficient time between them, when workers voluntarily agree to return to work during rest periods without understanding their rights, or when business pressures create expectations that rest periods will be shortened. Such violations are illegal regardless of worker consent; rest periods are minimum legal rights that cannot be waived. Workers who work with insufficient rest periods should raise the issue with the employer and document the violations.

If rest period violations occur repeatedly or systematically, workers can file complaints with labor inspectorate, which has authority to investigate, order corrections, and impose fines. Labor inspectors particularly focus on working time violations in hospitality due to the sector's history of non-compliance. Workers may also have claims for compensatory damages if inadequate rest caused demonstrable harm (fatigue-related illness, accidents). Collective agreements may specify specific compensation for rest period violations, such as premium pay or additional rest time. Employers should proactively schedule work to ensure compliance rather than risking sanctions and worker health harm.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Rest Facilities and Break Areas
subsections.content:
While not strictly part of working time regulation, the quality of rest breaks is enhanced by appropriate facilities. Employers should provide: break areas separate from customer areas and work operations where workers can rest without work-related interruptions; comfortable seating, particularly important for hospitality workers who stand throughout shifts; facilities for consuming meals and drinks including heating equipment for brought meals; access to drinking water; and clean, hygienic toilet facilities. Denying access to toilets or requiring workers to remain in customer view during breaks undermines rest quality.

For establishments with shift work or night work, additional facilities may be required: rest areas where workers can lie down during extended breaks or for workers feeling unwell; lockers for personal belongings; and changing facilities where uniforms or work clothing is required. These facilities support not only compliance with rest period requirements but also worker dignity, comfort, and wellbeing. Investment in good facilities demonstrates respect for workers and contributes to satisfaction and retention.

sections.heading: 3. Overtime Regulation and Compensation
sections.content:
Overtime is working time performed beyond ordinary working hours. Article 35 of the Workers' Statute limits overtime to maximum 80 hours per year per worker. Hours worked beyond ordinary hours due to force majeure (genuine emergencies requiring immediate response to prevent damage or danger) are excluded from this limit and must be worked, but other overtime must be voluntary — workers cannot be required to work overtime as a regular practice. In practice, hospitality workers often face pressure to work overtime due to understaffing or unexpected business, creating tension between legal voluntary nature of overtime and workplace realities.

Overtime must be compensated either by payment or by compensatory rest time (time off in lieu). Payment must be at the rate established in collective agreement or, if not specified, at a rate not less than ordinary hourly rate. Many hospitality collective agreements specify enhanced rates such as 175% of ordinary hourly rate for overtime. Compensatory rest must be provided within four months following the overtime work at a 1:1 ratio (one hour overtime = one hour time off) or at enhanced ratios if provided in collective agreements. The choice between payment and compensatory rest is typically determined by collective agreement or, in its absence, by agreement between employer and worker.

Recording overtime is essential for compliance with the 80-hour annual limit and for ensuring proper compensation. Daily time records must capture overtime hours separately. Workers should verify that overtime is accurately recorded and appropriately compensated. If overtime is neither paid nor compensated with time off, workers can claim unpaid salary for overtime hours worked. If overtime exceeds 80 hours annually, workers can file labor inspectorate complaints for legal violations. Systematic excessive overtime may also indicate inadequate staffing levels, creating occupational health concerns that should be addressed through risk assessment and prevention measures.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Distinguishing Overtime from Irregular Distribution
subsections.content:
Not all hours beyond 40 in a particular week constitute overtime. If the employment contract or collective agreement provides for irregular distribution of working time (distribución irregular de la jornada), weekly hours can vary within specified limits (typically 10-20% above and below average) with compensating variations in other weeks, and these variations are ordinary working time, not overtime. Overtime exists only when total annual hours exceed the annual ordinary working time (typically 1,800 hours annually for 40-hour weeks accounting for holidays).

This distinction is important for compensation. Irregular distribution hours are paid at ordinary rates, while overtime hours are paid at enhanced rates or compensated with time off. Employers sometimes mischaracterize systematic overtime as irregular distribution to avoid paying enhanced rates. Workers should verify: does the contract or collective agreement explicitly provide for irregular distribution; are busy period excess hours genuinely compensated by reduced hours in slow periods (if not, they are overtime not irregular distribution); and are annual total hours remaining within ordinary working time limits. If doubt exists, workers should consult union representatives or labor lawyers for clarification.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Force Majeure Overtime
subsections.content:
Force majeure overtime — hours worked in response to genuine emergencies such as urgent repairs preventing building damage, responses to serious accidents, or extraordinary situations requiring immediate attention to prevent harm — is not subject to the 80-hour annual limit and is not voluntary. Workers must work force majeure overtime when required. However, force majeure overtime must be genuinely related to emergencies, not routine business needs or poor planning by employers. A sudden private event requiring additional staffing or a rush order from a demanding customer is not force majeure.

Force majeure overtime must still be compensated. Collective agreements or, in their absence, negotiation between employer and worker determine compensation. Payment at enhanced rates or compensatory rest are typical. Workers should ensure force majeure overtime is recorded separately and properly compensated. If employers routinely invoke force majeure for ordinary overtime, workers should challenge this as it likely indicates either genuine understaffing that should be addressed or mischaracterization to evade the 80-hour limit.

sections.heading: 4. Working Time Recording Requirements
sections.content:
Royal Decree-Law 8/2019 mandates that employers maintain reliable daily records of the actual working time of each worker, showing exact start and end times. This requirement responds to widespread working time violations, particularly undocumented overtime and excessive hours. The recording system must be objective and reliable (electronic time clocks, computerized systems, or in small operations, written sign-in sheets with worker and employer signatures). Purely theoretical schedules or estimates are insufficient; actual worked time must be recorded.

Records must be accessible to workers, their legal representatives, and labor inspectors at any time. Workers have the right to receive copies of their own records upon request, allowing verification that recorded hours match actually worked hours and ensuring accountability. Records must be retained for four years, as this is the limitation period for most labor claims in Spain. If inspectors find missing or inadequate records, or if records show working time violations, significant fines can be imposed (€626-€6,250 per affected worker for serious infractions, €6,251-€187,515 for very serious infractions).

Practical implementation requires that workers clock in/out or sign in/out at start and end of each shift, including overtime and any mid-shift absences. Employers must ensure the recording system is accessible, functional, and accurately captures working time. Manipulating records to conceal violations (recording fewer hours than actually worked, failing to record overtime) is an additional serious infraction. Workers who observe that recorded hours do not match actual hours worked should raise this immediately with the employer and, if not corrected, with worker representatives or labor inspectorate. Accurate time recording protects both parties: workers have evidence for claims if underpaid, and employers have evidence of compliance if challenged.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Common Time Recording Issues in Hospitality
subsections.content:
Hospitality presents specific time recording challenges: variable shift start and end times make fixed schedules inadequate documentation; workers may start early or finish late to complete tasks (cleaning, preparation, closing procedures) which must be recorded; split shifts with long unpaid breaks require recording four time points per day; on-call or irregular schedules require flexible recording systems; and some small establishments lack technological systems and must rely on manual records.

Workers should ensure: they clock/sign in immediately when starting work (including arrival time for preparation before official shift start); they clock/sign out at actual finish time (including time for closing duties after last customer service); breaks are recorded if they affect total working time calculations; and overtime or extra shifts are recorded. Employers should not require workers to perform tasks before clocking in or after clocking out, as this creates unrecorded working time. If technical issues prevent clocking in/out (broken system, forgotten sign-in), alternative documentation (supervisors' confirmation, written notes) should be created immediately to maintain accurate records.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Using Time Records for Rights Enforcement
subsections.content:
Accurate time records are essential evidence for enforcing working time rights. Workers pursuing overtime pay claims can submit time records showing hours worked beyond ordinary hours. Workers claiming excessive hours or inadequate rest can present records showing violations. Conversely, employers defending against such claims will rely on time records showing compliance. Therefore, workers should: periodically request copies of their own time records to verify accuracy; immediately report any discrepancies (hours shown in records don't match actual hours worked); maintain personal records (calendars, diaries) noting actual hours worked as backup evidence if official records are disputed; and preserve time records if anticipating claims, as four-year retention requirement means older records may be destroyed.

In disputes over whether time records are accurate, labor courts assess credibility of competing evidence. Official time records enjoy presumption of accuracy, but workers can rebut this with credible alternative evidence (personal records, witness testimony from colleagues, indirect evidence like text messages discussing actual working hours). Courts often find that certain patterns (time records showing perfect adherence to scheduled hours every day) are suspiciously regular given typical operational realities, suggesting record manipulation. Workers' consistent personal records and credible testimony can overcome inadequate official records.

sections.heading: 5. Special Working Time Situations
sections.content:
Certain working time situations require specific understanding and management. Night work (22:00-06:00) is subject to special provisions: workers classified as night workers (regularly working at least 3 hours nightly or one-third of annual hours at night) cannot exceed 8-hour average per 24-hour period over 15-day reference, receive mandatory health surveillance, and may receive premium pay or other compensation per collective agreements. Night work is prohibited for workers under 18. Pregnant workers can request exemption from night work if medically advised.

Sunday and holiday work is not prohibited in hospitality (unlike some sectors where Sunday work is restricted), but collective agreements typically provide compensatory measures: premium pay supplements for hours worked on Sundays or designated holidays; additional rest days compensating for Sunday/holiday work; or preference systems where Sunday/holiday work is rotated equitably rather than concentrated on certain workers. Workers should verify that compensation specified in collective agreements for Sunday and holiday work is actually provided.

On-call time (availability without actually working) has nuanced treatment. If workers must remain at the workplace ready to work immediately, this is working time for all purposes. If workers can be at home or elsewhere but must be reachable and able to respond within a short timeframe, treatment depends on restrictions imposed: highly restrictive on-call (must respond within 15-30 minutes, cannot consume alcohol, cannot be far from workplace) may be considered working time or require compensation; less restrictive on-call (respond within several hours, few activity restrictions) may be compensated at lower rates or flat availability fees. Collective agreements often specify on-call compensation. European Court of Justice case law increasingly treats restrictive on-call as working time.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Seasonal Work and Annualized Hours
subsections.content:
Seasonal hospitality businesses (beach restaurants, ski resort hotels, summer event venues) often use annualized hours contracts where workers work intensive periods (long hours, six-day weeks) during high season and reduced or no hours during off-season, with average annual hours remaining within limits. Discontinuous permanent contracts (fijo discontinuo) are specifically designed for seasonal recurring work, providing job security across seasons while allowing activity periods and inactivity periods aligned with business cycles.

For annualized hours arrangements to be legal, several conditions must be met: the arrangement must be specified in employment contract or collective agreement; intensive periods must be compensated by genuinely reduced hours in other periods (not just dismissal or unpaid layoff during off-season); average annual hours must not exceed ordinary working time limits; and daily maximum and rest period minimums must be respected even during intensive periods. Workers in seasonal roles should verify that total annual hours and annual compensation provide fair overall working conditions, not exploitation of willingness to work intensive periods without corresponding off-period compensation.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Shift Work and Rotation Patterns
subsections.content:
Shift work (multiple shifts covering extended or continuous operating hours) requires careful management of working time and rest. Rotation patterns should be: planned and communicated in advance, providing predictability for workers to organize personal life; equitable, distributing desirable and undesirable shifts fairly among workers rather than concentrating night shifts or weekend shifts on certain individuals; physiologically appropriate, using forward rotation (day-evening-night) which is better tolerated than backward rotation; and respectful of individual circumstances, providing some flexibility for workers with care responsibilities, education, or other constraints.

Rapid rotation (changing shift pattern every 2-3 days) prevents biological adaptation to night shifts, reducing some long-term health impacts of night work, but creates continuous adjustment challenges. Slow rotation (weeks or months on one shift type) allows adaptation but can create entrenched circadian disruption and make day-shift workers and night-shift workers feel like separate populations. Permanent assignment to preferred shifts (some workers prefer consistent night shifts) can work if it is genuinely voluntary and not imposed on unwilling workers. Employers should consult workers on rotation patterns and accommodate preferences where operationally feasible.

sections.heading: 6. Enforcement and Worker Rights Protection
sections.content:
Workers experiencing working time violations — excessive hours, inadequate rest, unpaid overtime, missing time records — have multiple enforcement avenues. Internal resolution should be attempted first: raise the issue with supervisors or management, document the violations and communications, and request correction. If the employer is responsive, many issues can be resolved at this stage. If internal resolution fails or if violations are systematic, external enforcement becomes necessary.

Labor inspectorate complaints (Inspección de Trabajo) can be filed for statutory violations: exceeding maximum hours, violating rest period requirements, missing or inadequate time records, or unpaid overtime. Labor inspectors have authority to access workplaces, examine records, interview workers and management, order corrections, and impose administrative fines. Complaints can be filed online, by mail, or in person at provincial labor offices. Complainant identity can be kept confidential from the employer if requested, though in small workplaces, investigating specific complaints may make the complainant's identity inferrable.

Labor court claims (reclamaciones ante el Juzgado de lo Social) are appropriate for individual rights enforcement requiring compensation: unpaid overtime, underpayment due to working time miscalculation, or damages from working time violations causing harm. Labor court procedures are relatively accessible and quick (typically 4-6 months from claim to judgment), with streamlined processes designed to not require lawyers for simple claims (though legal representation significantly improves success rates). Trade unions often provide free legal representation to members for labor claims. Time limits apply to claims (typically one year for salary claims from date payment was due), so workers should not delay excessively in pursuing rights enforcement.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Protection Against Retaliation
subsections.content:
Workers who complain about working time violations or refuse to work excessive hours are protected against retaliation. Dismissal or unfavorable treatment in response to exercising working time rights is prohibited and can result in: dismissal being declared void or unfair with reinstatement and back pay; compensation for damages caused by retaliatory treatment; and additional administrative sanctions against the employer for retaliation. Workers experiencing retaliation should document the sequence: when they raised working time concerns, what specific concerns were raised, and what adverse treatment followed. Temporal proximity (dismissal or sanction shortly after complaint) creates presumption of retaliatory motivation.

Protection is strongest when workers exercise rights through official channels (written complaints to employer, labor inspectorate complaints, union grievances) creating clear documentation. However, protection also extends to informal assertion of rights (telling supervisor you won't work more overtime because you've exceeded legal limits, refusing to work with insufficient rest period). Workers should balance self-protection (documenting and using official channels) with practical workplace dynamics, potentially seeking union or legal support when facing retaliation threats.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Collective Action and Union Role
subsections.content:
Working time issues often affect multiple workers and may reflect systemic employer practices (chronic understaffing, routine excessive hours, pressure to skip breaks). Collective responses through union action can be more effective than individual complaints. Unions can: negotiate working time improvements in collective agreement revisions; file collective complaints with labor inspectorate for systemic violations affecting multiple workers; represent workers collectively in disputes with employers; and organize workplace actions (work-to-rule campaigns, refused overtime campaigns) to pressure employer compliance.

Worker representatives have specific rights regarding working time issues: they must be consulted on working time arrangements and schedule changes; they can access workplace time records to monitor compliance; they can represent workers in grievances related to working time; and they have protected status making dismissal or sanction more difficult. Workers facing working time problems should consider: joining unions to access collective representation and support; electing effective worker representatives who will prioritize working time compliance; and supporting collective efforts to improve conditions rather than only pursuing individual remedies. Ultimately, sustainable improvements in working time compliance require both individual rights enforcement and collective pressure for systemic change.

checklists.title: Daily Working Time Compliance Checklist
items: Clock in/record exact start time when beginning work (including preparation before official shift)
Record any mid-shift breaks or absences
Clock out/record exact end time when ceasing work (including completion tasks after service)
Verify total daily hours do not exceed 9 hours unless exceptional circumstances justified
Verify minimum 12-hour rest period between end of today's shift and start of next shift
If working over 6 continuous hours, verify you received at least 15-minute break
If working overtime, ensure overtime is recorded separately from ordinary hours
If working night hours (22:00-06:00), verify appropriate recording for night work tracking
Keep personal record (diary, calendar) noting actual hours worked for verification
Report any discrepancies between actual hours worked and recorded hours immediately

checklists.title: Weekly/Monthly Working Time Review Checklist
items: Calculate total hours worked in the week/month from time records
Verify weekly rest of at least 1.5 days (36 hours uninterrupted) was provided
If working irregular schedule, verify busy period excess hours balanced by reduced hours elsewhere
Calculate any overtime hours (beyond ordinary hours limits) and verify compensation
Check that overtime compensation (payment or time off) matches collective agreement rates
Verify total hours remain within reasonable weekly averages trending toward annual limit
Request copy of your time records from employer to verify accuracy
Document any weeks with excessive hours, inadequate rest, or unpaid overtime for potential claims
If working part-time, verify recorded hours do not regularly exceed contracted hours without compensation
Raise concerns about systematic excessive hours or inadequate rest with employer or representatives

checklists.title: Annual Working Time Assessment Checklist
items: Calculate total hours worked in the year from complete time records
Verify total annual hours do not exceed ordinary working time limit (typically 1,800 hours for 40-hour weeks)
Calculate total overtime hours for the year and verify not exceeding 80-hour annual limit
Verify all overtime was compensated either by payment or compensatory time off
For annualized hours or seasonal contracts, verify intensive periods balanced by reduced periods
Review annual salary against total hours to calculate effective hourly rate
Compare effective hourly rate to minimum salary requirements in collective agreement
Identify patterns of systematic violations (routine excessive hours, unpaid overtime, missing rest)
If violations identified, calculate economic impact (unpaid overtime value, rest violation premiums)
Consider filing formal complaint or claim if systematic violations and informal resolution unsuccessful
Consult union representative or labor lawyer about enforcement options and time limits
Maintain all time records and documentation supporting potential claims

bestPractices: Maintain personal working time records (diary, calendar, photos of schedules) as backup documentation in case official records are disputed or unavailable
Request copies of your official time records quarterly to verify accuracy and address discrepancies while still current
Understand your annual working time entitlement and overtime limits; calculate running totals to know your position
Assert your right to mandatory breaks and rest periods; declining breaks harms your health and creates precedent undermining rights
If offered choice between overtime payment and compensatory time off, consider which better serves your needs (payment vs. time off)
Join trade unions which can provide interpretation of working time rights, representation in disputes, and collective pressure for compliance
Report systematic working time violations affecting multiple workers to labor inspectorate; inspections protect all workers
Support election of effective worker representatives who will monitor working time compliance and represent workers on scheduling issues

glossary.Ordinary Working Time: Standard working hours before overtime; maximum 40 hours per week averaged annually, 9 hours per day
glossary.Overtime: Hours worked beyond ordinary working time limits; maximum 80 hours per year, must be compensated at enhanced rate or with time off
glossary.Split Shift: Working day divided into two periods separated by unpaid break of several hours; common in hospitality for lunch/dinner service
glossary.Daily Rest: Minimum 12 consecutive hours between end of one working day and start of next; protects recovery and health
glossary.Weekly Rest: Minimum 1.5 consecutive days (36 hours) rest per week; preferably including Sunday
glossary.Working Time Recording: Legal requirement to maintain daily records of exact start and end times worked by each employee; mandatory since 2019
glossary.Irregular Distribution: Working time arrangement allowing weekly hours to vary within limits, with compensating variations maintaining average annual compliance
glossary.Night Work: Work performed between 22:00 and 06:00; subject to special health surveillance and working time limits for night workers
glossary.Force Majeure Overtime: Overtime worked in genuine emergencies to prevent harm or damage; not subject to 80-hour annual limit, not voluntary
